Types of whales: meet the largest animals in the ocean
Types of whales: meet the largest animals in the ocean

April 3, 2024




Want to protect ocean life?Join IFAW
Whales are magnificent creatures. Not only are they highly intelligent, complex communicators, and the largest living animals on our planet, but they also protect us and the environment by providing the nutrients that help phytoplankton (tiny marine organisms that use photosynthesis) produce more than 50% of the world’s oxygen. 
Did you know that all species of whales are grouped into just two suborders? There are 76 species of odontocetes (toothed whales), which use teeth to hunt for prey, and 14 species of mysticetes (baleen whales), which use baleen plates to filter food from the water. Baleen consists of bristle-like structures made from keratin—the same protein that makes human hair and fingernails.  
Baleen whales evolved from toothed whales, and they are some of the largest animal species on Earth. Toothed whales, on the other hand, are smaller on average, and this group also contains dolphins and porpoises. While baleen whales eat tiny organisms like krill and zooplankton, toothed whales feed on larger animals like fish and squid. 
Here are some different types of whales within these two groups, how to identify them, and what makes them so unique. 
Mysticetes (baleen whales) 
Humpback whale 







Humpback Whale swimming off the coast of Tonga. Photo: © Vanessa Mignon




Acrobatic and charismatic, humpback whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) are one of the most well-known whale species and the stars of many whale watching tours. These baleen whales can grow to over 15 meters (50 feet) long and weigh over 36 metric tonnes (40 US tons). 
Humpback whales are easily recognized by their long pectoral fins, which are the longest of any whale species—one-third of their body length. The humpback whale’s scientific name translates to ‘big-winged New Englander’. They also have an irregularly shaped dorsal fin and a hump that gives them their common name. 
Knobby bumps on a humpback’s head are enlarged hair follicles called tubercles, which each contain at least one sensory hair. Their tails—called flukes—are unique to each individual, much like human fingerprints. Black and white patterns along with scarring on the underside of a humpback whale’s fluke help to identify it as an individual. 

Blue whale 







Blue whale swimming underwater. Photo: © Darin Sakdatorn - stock.adobe.com




The blue whale (Balaenoptera musculus) is the largest animal on Earth. This baleen whale can grow up to 30 meters (100 feet) long and weigh as much as 90 metric tonnes (100 US tons)—their tongues alone weigh as much as an elephant! Blue whales are sleek and slender, and their streamlined, blue-grey bodies appear bright blue underwater, which gave them their name. 
In addition to being the largest, blue whales are also the loudest animals on Earth. They can emit low-frequency vocalizations as loud as a jet plane, which are heard by other whales hundreds of miles away. 

Right whale 







Aerial view of North Atlantic right whales (Eubalaena glacialis) at the surface of the water. Photo: © Nick Hawkins




The right whale gets its name from the fact that whalers called it the ‘right’ whale to hunt due to its slow swimming speed and large amount of blubber, which was used for its oil. As a result, right whales have been hunted to near extinction. Commercial whaling has been banned since 1986 around the world, but the practice continues in a few countries using loopholes in regulations. Today, all populations of right whales are protected by law. 
There are four species of right whale: the North Atlantic right whale (Eubalaena glacialis), North Pacific right whale (Eubalaena japonica), Southern right whale (Eubalaena australis), and bowhead whale (Balaena mysticetus). The North Atlantic right whale is one of the most endangered species of whales in the world—there are only about 350 remaining. IFAW is leading efforts to protect this critically endangered species from the dangers of entanglement in fishing gear, underwater noise pollution, and vessel strikes. 
Right whales can grow up to 15 meters (50 feet) long and weigh up to 63 metric tonnes (70 US tons). They have stocky, black bodies with white patches on their undersides. They lack a dorsal fin and have paddle-like pectoral flippers along with broad, smooth-edged flukes that help propel their massive bodies. 
One of the most distinct features of right whales are their huge heads, which have roughened white patches called callosities. These are covered in whale lice, called cyamids. Each individual right whale has its own unique pattern of callosities, making them a perfect way for researchers to identify individuals. 
Another distinctive characteristic of a right whale is the V-shaped blow or spout produced when it takes a breath. 

Fin whale 







Fin whale surfacing. Photo: © IFAW




The second largest animal on Earth next to the blue whale is the fin whale (Balaenoptera physalus), also known as the finback whale. Named for its prominent dorsal fin, which is two thirds of the way back on its body, the fin whale can grow up to 24 meters (80 feet) long and weigh up to 63 metric tonnes (70 US tons). 
One of the fastest swimming whales, fin whales are nicknamed the ‘greyhounds of the sea’. Fin whales belong to the rorqual family—a group of whales that also includes blue whales and humpbacks—which means they have pleats or grooves around their throat that expand to take in massive amounts of water and prey. This is the perfect adaptation to grow to massive sizes! 
Fin whales have streamlined grey bodies with irregular white patches called chevrons that begin behind their blowholes and continue down onto their sides. They also have asymmetrical coloration—the lower right of their jaw is white, while the rest of their jaw is grey. It’s thought that this asymmetry helps them corral prey while they are hunting. 
In Iceland, fin whales sadly continue to be hunted. Partnered with IceWhale, IFAW created the Meet Us, Don’t Eat Us campaign in Iceland to gain support for sustainable whale watching instead of commercial whaling and consumption. 
Other baleen whales include minke whales, grey whales, sei whales, Bryde’s whales, Rice’s whales, Omura’s whales, and pygmy right whales. 
Odontocetes (toothed whales) 
Sperm whale 







Sperm whale swimming in the ocean. Photo: © Vanessa Mignon




Sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalus) are the largest toothed whales—as such, they are the world’s largest toothed predators. Growing up to 18 meters (60 feet) long and weighing 40 metric tonnes (45 US tons), the sperm whale has a dark grey body with a wrinkled appearance. It has a small jaw and a large, blunt head with one blowhole off centre on the left side. 
Sperm whales are some of the deepest diving whales, spending more than an hour on dives at depths up to 600 meters to hunt for giant squid. While diving, they use echolocation clicks and pulses. 
A primary target in commercial whaling, sperm whales are named for the waxy oil in the organ called their melon, a mass of tissue at the front of a whale’s head. This oil, called spermaceti, was used in products like candles and oil lamps. Nearly decimated by hunting in the 1800s, sperm whales are now endangered and protected throughout their range. 

Orca 







A killer whale at the surface in Iceland. Photo: Richard McLanaghan / © IFAW




Also known as the killer whale, the orca (Orcinus orca) is one of the most well recognized whales in the ocean, thanks to their distinct black and white color patterns. Technically considered the largest dolphin, the orca can grow up to 9 meters (32 feet) long and weigh up to 8 tonnes (9 metric tonnes). A male orca has a tall, triangular dorsal fin that can reach up to 2 meters (6 feet) high, while females have smaller, curved dorsal fins. 
One of the most well-studied species in the world, orcas are highly intelligent and have complex social structures. They are known to be fierce hunters and have earned the nickname ‘wolves of the sea’. 

Beluga whale 







A group of beluga whales. Photo: Alexander Lyskin / © IFAW




The beluga whale (Delphinapterus leucas) is a species of toothed whale that lives in the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions of the Northern Hemisphere. Belugas grow up to 4.5 meters (15 feet) long and weigh up to 1.3 metric tonnes (1.5 US tons). 
Belugas can be recognized by their uniform white color, which is how they received their name—beluga translates to ‘white’ in Russian. They have a round head with a bulbous forehead, where their melon organ is located. 
As one of the most vocal whale species, belugas received the nickname ‘sea canaries’ by early mariners, who could hear their vocalizations through the hulls of their boats. 
Other types of toothed whales include beaked whales, dwarf and pygmy sperm whales, narwhals, and all dolphins and porpoises. 
How can you help? 
All whale species are incredibly important for the health of their ecosystems and the ocean as a whole. They circulate nutrients, feed phytoplankton, store carbon, and help us combat climate change. Without whales, our oceans and planet—and countless animal species—would be in danger. 
Unfortunately, deadly threats like ocean noise pollution, plastic pollution, collisions with vessels, whaling, and entanglement in fishing gear continue to push many whale species closer to extinction. Whale watching is a great economic alternative to whaling, and other initiatives to protect whales include whale-safe lobster fishing gear and vessel speed restrictions. 
Learn more about these threats and how IFAW is working to protect whales.

%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EDid%20you%20know%20that%20all%20species%20of%20whales%20are%20grouped%20into%20just%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fjournal%2Fwhat-is-marine-mammal-complete-guide%5C%22%3Etwo%20suborders%3C%2Fa%3E%3F%20There%20are%2076%20species%20of%20odontocetes%20(toothed%20whales)%2C%20which%20use%20teeth%20to%20hunt%20for%20prey%2C%20and%2014%20species%20of%20mysticetes%20(baleen%20whales)%2C%20which%20use%20baleen%20plates%20to%20filter%20food%20from%20the%20water.%20Baleen%20consists%20of%20bristle-like%20structures%20made%20from%20keratin%E2%80%94the%20same%20protein%20that%20makes%20human%20hair%20and%20fingernails.%26nbsp%3B%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EBaleen%20whales%20evolved%20from%20toothed%20whales%2C%20and%20they%20are%20some%20of%20the%20largest%20animal%20species%20on%20Earth.%20Toothed%20whales%2C%20on%20the%20other%20hand%2C%20are%20smaller%20on%20average%2C%20and%20this%20group%20also%20contains%20dolphins%20and%20porpoises.%20While%20baleen%20whales%20eat%20tiny%20organisms%20like%20krill%20and%20zooplankton%2C%20toothed%20whales%20feed%20on%20larger%20animals%20like%20fish%20and%20squid.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EHere%20are%20some%20different%20types%20of%20whales%20within%20these%20two%20groups%2C%20how%20to%20identify%20them%2C%20and%20what%20makes%20them%20so%20unique.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cstrong%3EMysticetes%20(baleen%20whales)%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fstrong%3E%3C%2Fh2%3E%3Ch5%3EHumpback%20whale%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407353%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191043%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F1319%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2FMignon0W0A3760_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F1319%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2FMignon0W0A3760_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F1319%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2FMignon0W0A3760_reduced.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F1319%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2FMignon0W0A3760_reduced.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F1319%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2FMignon0W0A3760_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22Humpback%20Whale%20swimming%20off%20the%20coast%20of%20Tonga.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22Humpback%20Whale%20swimming%20off%20the%20coast%20of%20Tonga.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20%C2%A9%20Vanessa%20Mignon%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407354%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407354%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EAcrobatic%20and%20charismatic%2C%20humpback%20whales%20(%3Cem%3EMegaptera%20novaeangliae%3C%2Fem%3E)%20are%20one%20of%20the%20most%20well-known%20whale%20species%20and%20the%20stars%20of%20many%20whale%20watching%20tours.%20These%20baleen%20whales%20can%20grow%20to%20over%2015%20meters%20(50%20feet)%20long%20and%20weigh%20over%2036%20metric%20tonnes%20(40%20US%20tons).%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EHumpback%20whales%20are%20easily%20recognized%20by%20their%20long%20pectoral%20fins%2C%20which%20are%20the%20longest%20of%20any%20whale%20species%E2%80%94one-third%20of%20their%20body%20length.%20The%20humpback%20whale%E2%80%99s%20scientific%20name%20translates%20to%20%E2%80%98big-winged%20New%20Englander%E2%80%99.%20They%20also%20have%20an%20irregularly%20shaped%20dorsal%20fin%20and%20a%20hump%20that%20gives%20them%20their%20common%20name.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EKnobby%20bumps%20on%20a%20humpback%E2%80%99s%20head%20are%20enlarged%20hair%20follicles%20called%20tubercles%2C%20which%20each%20contain%20at%20least%20one%20sensory%20hair.%20Their%20tails%E2%80%94called%20flukes%E2%80%94are%20unique%20to%20each%20individual%2C%20much%20like%20human%20fingerprints.%20Black%20and%20white%20patterns%20along%20with%20scarring%20on%20the%20underside%20of%20a%20humpback%20whale%E2%80%99s%20fluke%20help%20to%20identify%20it%20as%20an%20individual.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch5%3E%3Cbr%3EBlue%20whale%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407355%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191044%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F3875%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2FAdobeStock_281064827_340032_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F3875%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2FAdobeStock_281064827_340032_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F3875%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2FAdobeStock_281064827_340032_reduced.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F3875%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2FAdobeStock_281064827_340032_reduced.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F3875%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2FAdobeStock_281064827_340032_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22Blue%20whale%20swimming%20underwater.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22Blue%20whale%20swimming%20underwater.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20%C2%A9%20Darin%20Sakdatorn%20-%20stock.adobe.com%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407356%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407356%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Fblue-whales%5C%22%3Eblue%20whale%3C%2Fa%3E%20(%3Cem%3EBalaenoptera%20musculus%3C%2Fem%3E)%20is%20the%20largest%20animal%20on%20Earth.%20This%20baleen%20whale%20can%20grow%20up%20to%2030%20meters%20(100%20feet)%20long%20and%20weigh%20as%20much%20as%2090%20metric%20tonnes%20(100%20US%20tons)%E2%80%94their%20tongues%20alone%20weigh%20as%20much%20as%20an%20elephant!%20Blue%20whales%20are%20sleek%20and%20slender%2C%20and%20their%20streamlined%2C%20blue-grey%20bodies%20appear%20bright%20blue%20underwater%2C%20which%20gave%20them%20their%20name.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20addition%20to%20being%20the%20largest%2C%20blue%20whales%20are%20also%20the%20loudest%20animals%20on%20Earth.%20They%20can%20emit%20low-frequency%20vocalizations%20as%20loud%20as%20a%20jet%20plane%2C%20which%20are%20heard%20by%20other%20whales%20hundreds%20of%20miles%20away.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch5%3E%3Cbr%3ERight%20whale%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407357%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191045%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2306%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2FMC_20161001_CAN_NARW_001_332746_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2306%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2FMC_20161001_CAN_NARW_001_332746_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2306%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2FMC_20161001_CAN_NARW_001_332746_reduced.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2306%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2FMC_20161001_CAN_NARW_001_332746_reduced.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2306%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2FMC_20161001_CAN_NARW_001_332746_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22Aerial%20view%20of%20North%20Atlantic%20right%20whales%20(Eubalaena%20glacialis)%20at%20the%20surface%20of%20the%20water.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22Aerial%20view%20of%20North%20Atlantic%20right%20whales%20(Eubalaena%20glacialis)%20at%20the%20surface%20of%20the%20water.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20%C2%A9%20Nick%20Hawkins%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407358%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407358%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20right%20whale%20gets%20its%20name%20from%20the%20fact%20that%20whalers%20called%20it%20the%20%E2%80%98right%E2%80%99%20whale%20to%20hunt%20due%20to%20its%20slow%20swimming%20speed%20and%20large%20amount%20of%20blubber%2C%20which%20was%20used%20for%20its%20oil.%20As%20a%20result%2C%20right%20whales%20have%20been%20hunted%20to%20near%20extinction.%20Commercial%20whaling%20has%20been%20banned%20since%201986%20around%20the%20world%2C%20but%20the%20practice%20continues%20in%20a%20few%20countries%20using%20loopholes%20in%20regulations.%20Today%2C%20all%20populations%20of%20right%20whales%20are%20protected%20by%20law.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EThere%20are%20four%20species%20of%20right%20whale%3A%20the%20North%20Atlantic%20right%20whale%20(%3Cem%3EEubalaena%20glacialis%3C%2Fem%3E)%2C%20North%20Pacific%20right%20whale%20(%3Cem%3EEubalaena%20japonica%3C%2Fem%3E)%2C%20Southern%20right%20whale%20(%3Cem%3EEubalaena%20australis%3C%2Fem%3E)%2C%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Fbowhead-whales%5C%22%3Ebowhead%20whale%3C%2Fa%3E%20(%3Cem%3EBalaena%20mysticetus%3C%2Fem%3E).%20The%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Fnorth-atlantic-right-whale%5C%22%3ENorth%20Atlantic%20right%20whale%3C%2Fa%3E%20is%20one%20of%20the%20most%20endangered%20species%20of%20whales%20in%20the%20world%E2%80%94there%20are%20only%20about%20350%20remaining.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fcampaigns%2Fsaving-the-north-atlantic-right-whale%5C%22%3EIFAW%20is%20leading%20efforts%3C%2Fa%3E%20to%20protect%20this%20critically%20endangered%20species%20from%20the%20dangers%20of%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fjournal%2Fnorth-atlantic-right-whales-terms-and-definitions%5C%22%3Eentanglement%20in%20fishing%20gear%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fbluespeeds.org%2F%5C%22%20target%3D%5C%22_blank%5C%22%3Eunderwater%20noise%20pollution%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fresources%2Fship-strikes-whales-prevention-factsheet%5C%22%3Evessel%20strikes%3C%2Fa%3E.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3ERight%20whales%20can%20grow%20up%20to%2015%20meters%20(50%20feet)%20long%20and%20weigh%20up%20to%2063%20metric%20tonnes%20(70%20US%20tons).%20They%20have%20stocky%2C%20black%20bodies%20with%20white%20patches%20on%20their%20undersides.%20They%20lack%20a%20dorsal%20fin%20and%20have%20paddle-like%20pectoral%20flippers%20along%20with%20broad%2C%20smooth-edged%20flukes%20that%20help%20propel%20their%20massive%20bodies.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EOne%20of%20the%20most%20distinct%20features%20of%20right%20whales%20are%20their%20huge%20heads%2C%20which%20have%20roughened%20white%20patches%20called%20callosities.%20These%20are%20covered%20in%20whale%20lice%2C%20called%20cyamids.%20Each%20individual%20right%20whale%20has%20its%20own%20unique%20pattern%20of%20callosities%2C%20making%20them%20a%20perfect%20way%20for%20researchers%20to%20identify%20individuals.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EAnother%20distinctive%20characteristic%20of%20a%20right%20whale%20is%20the%20V-shaped%20blow%20or%20spout%20produced%20when%20it%20takes%20a%20breath.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch5%3E%3Cbr%3EFin%20whale%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407359%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191046%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4533%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2FDSC_5262_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4533%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2FDSC_5262_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4533%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2FDSC_5262_reduced.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4533%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2FDSC_5262_reduced.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4533%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2FDSC_5262_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22Fin%20whale%20surfacing.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22Fin%20whale%20surfacing.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20%C2%A9%20IFAW%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407360%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407360%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20second%20largest%20animal%20on%20Earth%20next%20to%20the%20blue%20whale%20is%20the%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Ffin-whales%5C%22%3Efin%20whale%3C%2Fa%3E%20(%3Cem%3EBalaenoptera%20physalus%3C%2Fem%3E)%2C%20also%20known%20as%20the%20finback%20whale.%20Named%20for%20its%20prominent%20dorsal%20fin%2C%20which%20is%20two%20thirds%20of%20the%20way%20back%20on%20its%20body%2C%20the%20fin%20whale%20can%20grow%20up%20to%2024%20meters%20(80%20feet)%20long%20and%20weigh%20up%20to%2063%20metric%20tonnes%20(70%20US%20tons).%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EOne%20of%20the%20fastest%20swimming%20whales%2C%20fin%20whales%20are%20nicknamed%20the%20%E2%80%98greyhounds%20of%20the%20sea%E2%80%99.%20Fin%20whales%20belong%20to%20the%20rorqual%20family%E2%80%94a%20group%20of%20whales%20that%20also%20includes%20blue%20whales%20and%20humpbacks%E2%80%94which%20means%20they%20have%20pleats%20or%20grooves%20around%20their%20throat%20that%20expand%20to%20take%20in%20massive%20amounts%20of%20water%20and%20prey.%20This%20is%20the%20perfect%20adaptation%20to%20grow%20to%20massive%20sizes!%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EFin%20whales%20have%20streamlined%20grey%20bodies%20with%20irregular%20white%20patches%20called%20chevrons%20that%20begin%20behind%20their%20blowholes%20and%20continue%20down%20onto%20their%20sides.%20They%20also%20have%20asymmetrical%20coloration%E2%80%94the%20lower%20right%20of%20their%20jaw%20is%20white%2C%20while%20the%20rest%20of%20their%20jaw%20is%20grey.%20It%E2%80%99s%20thought%20that%20this%20asymmetry%20helps%20them%20corral%20prey%20while%20they%20are%20hunting.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EIn%20Iceland%2C%20fin%20whales%20sadly%20continue%20to%20be%20hunted.%20Partnered%20with%20IceWhale%2C%20IFAW%20created%20the%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.is%2F%5C%22%20target%3D%5C%22_blank%5C%22%3EMeet%20Us%2C%20Don%E2%80%99t%20Eat%20Us%3C%2Fa%3E%20campaign%20in%20Iceland%20to%20gain%20support%20for%20sustainable%20whale%20watching%20instead%20of%20commercial%20whaling%20and%20consumption.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EOther%20baleen%20whales%20include%20minke%20whales%2C%20grey%20whales%2C%20sei%20whales%2C%20Bryde%E2%80%99s%20whales%2C%20Rice%E2%80%99s%20whales%2C%20Omura%E2%80%99s%20whales%2C%20and%20pygmy%20right%20whales.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cstrong%3EOdontocetes%20(toothed%20whales)%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fstrong%3E%3C%2Fh2%3E%3Ch5%3ESperm%20whale%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407361%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191047%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2308%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2FMC_20180821_FRA_BeautyShots_037_334597_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2308%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2FMC_20180821_FRA_BeautyShots_037_334597_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2308%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2FMC_20180821_FRA_BeautyShots_037_334597_reduced.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2308%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2FMC_20180821_FRA_BeautyShots_037_334597_reduced.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2308%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2FMC_20180821_FRA_BeautyShots_037_334597_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22Sperm%20whale%20swimming%20in%20the%20ocean.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22Sperm%20whale%20swimming%20in%20the%20ocean.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20%C2%A9%20Vanessa%20Mignon%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407362%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407362%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ESperm%20whales%20(%3Cem%3EPhyseter%20macrocephalus%3C%2Fem%3E)%20are%20the%20largest%20toothed%20whales%E2%80%94as%20such%2C%20they%20are%20the%20world%E2%80%99s%20largest%20toothed%20predators.%20Growing%20up%20to%2018%20meters%20(60%20feet)%20long%20and%20weighing%2040%20metric%20tonnes%20(45%20US%20tons)%2C%20the%20sperm%20whale%20has%20a%20dark%20grey%20body%20with%20a%20wrinkled%20appearance.%20It%20has%20a%20small%20jaw%20and%20a%20large%2C%20blunt%20head%20with%20one%20blowhole%20off%20centre%20on%20the%20left%20side.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3ESperm%20whales%20are%20some%20of%20the%20deepest%20diving%20whales%2C%20spending%20more%20than%20an%20hour%20on%20dives%20at%20depths%20up%20to%20600%20meters%20to%20hunt%20for%20giant%20squid.%20While%20diving%2C%20they%20use%20echolocation%20clicks%20and%20pulses.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EA%20primary%20target%20in%20commercial%20whaling%2C%20sperm%20whales%20are%20named%20for%20the%20waxy%20oil%20in%20the%20organ%20called%20their%20melon%2C%20a%20mass%20of%20tissue%20at%20the%20front%20of%20a%20whale%E2%80%99s%20head.%20This%20oil%2C%20called%20spermaceti%2C%20was%20used%20in%20products%20like%20candles%20and%20oil%20lamps.%20Nearly%20decimated%20by%20hunting%20in%20the%201800s%2C%20sperm%20whales%20are%20now%20endangered%20and%20protected%20throughout%20their%20range.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch5%3E%3Cbr%3EOrca%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407363%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191048%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2307%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2FSOTW37_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2307%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2FSOTW37_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2307%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2FSOTW37_reduced.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2307%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2FSOTW37_reduced.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F2307%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2FSOTW37_reduced.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22A%20killer%20whale%20at%20the%20surface%20in%20Iceland.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22A%20killer%20whale%20at%20the%20surface%20in%20Iceland.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20Richard%20McLanaghan%20%2F%20%C2%A9%20IFAW%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407364%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407364%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EAlso%20known%20as%20the%20killer%20whale%2C%20the%20orca%20(%3Cem%3EOrcinus%20orca%3C%2Fem%3E)%20is%20one%20of%20the%20most%20well%20recognized%20whales%20in%20the%20ocean%2C%20thanks%20to%20their%20distinct%20black%20and%20white%20color%20patterns.%20Technically%20considered%20the%20largest%20dolphin%2C%20the%20orca%20can%20grow%20up%20to%209%20meters%20(32%20feet)%20long%20and%20weigh%20up%20to%208%20tonnes%20(9%20metric%20tonnes).%20A%20male%20orca%20has%20a%20tall%2C%20triangular%20dorsal%20fin%20that%20can%20reach%20up%20to%202%20meters%20(6%20feet)%20high%2C%20while%20females%20have%20smaller%2C%20curved%20dorsal%20fins.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EOne%20of%20the%20most%20well-studied%20species%20in%20the%20world%2C%20orcas%20are%20highly%20intelligent%20and%20have%20complex%20social%20structures.%20They%20are%20known%20to%20be%20fierce%20hunters%20and%20have%20earned%20the%20nickname%20%E2%80%98wolves%20of%20the%20sea%E2%80%99.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch5%3E%3Cbr%3EBeluga%20whale%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fh5%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407365%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_image%22%2C%22images%22%3A%5B%7B%22id%22%3A191049%2C%22regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4069%2Fimage%2Fs1300x1300%2Fbelugas_2.jpg%22%2C%22mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4069%2Fimage%2Fs768x1300%2Fbelugas_2.jpg%22%2C%22webp_regular%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4069%2Fimage%2Fp1300x1300%2Fbelugas_2.webp%22%2C%22webp_mobile%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4069%2Fimage%2Fp768x1300%2Fbelugas_2.webp%22%2C%22original%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fd1jyxxz9imt9yb.cloudfront.net%2Fmedialib%2F4069%2Fimage%2Foriginal%2Fbelugas_2.jpg%22%2C%22alt%22%3A%22A%20group%20of%20beluga%20whales.%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22A%20group%20of%20beluga%20whales.%22%2C%22credit%22%3A%22Photo%3A%20Alexander%20Lyskin%20%2F%20%C2%A9%20IFAW%22%2C%22hyperlink%22%3Anull%2C%22allow_download%22%3Afalse%2C%22kind%22%3A%22horizontal%22%7D%5D%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407366%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text%22%2C%22anchor%22%3A%22407366%22%2C%22text%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Fbelugas%5C%22%3Ebeluga%20whale%3C%2Fa%3E%20(%3Cem%3EDelphinapterus%20leucas%3C%2Fem%3E)%20is%20a%20species%20of%20toothed%20whale%20that%20lives%20in%20the%20Arctic%20and%20sub-Arctic%20regions%20of%20the%20Northern%20Hemisphere.%20Belugas%20grow%20up%20to%204.5%20meters%20(15%20feet)%20long%20and%20weigh%20up%20to%201.3%20metric%20tonnes%20(1.5%20US%20tons).%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EBelugas%20can%20be%20recognized%20by%20their%20uniform%20white%20color%2C%20which%20is%20how%20they%20received%20their%20name%E2%80%94beluga%20translates%20to%20%E2%80%98white%E2%80%99%20in%20Russian.%20They%20have%20a%20round%20head%20with%20a%20bulbous%20forehead%2C%20where%20their%20melon%20organ%20is%20located.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EAs%20one%20of%20the%20most%20vocal%20whale%20species%2C%20belugas%20received%20the%20nickname%20%E2%80%98sea%20canaries%E2%80%99%20by%20early%20mariners%2C%20who%20could%20hear%20their%20vocalizations%20through%20the%20hulls%20of%20their%20boats.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EOther%20types%20of%20toothed%20whales%20include%20beaked%20whales%2C%20dwarf%20and%20pygmy%20sperm%20whales%2C%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Fnarwhals%5C%22%3Enarwhals%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20and%20all%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fanimals%2Fdolphins%5C%22%3Edolphins%3C%2Fa%3E%20and%20porpoises.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Ch2%3E%3Cstrong%3EHow%20can%20you%20help%3F%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fstrong%3E%3C%2Fh2%3E%3Cp%3EAll%20whale%20species%20are%20incredibly%20important%20for%20the%20health%20of%20their%20ecosystems%20and%20the%20ocean%20as%20a%20whole.%20They%20circulate%20nutrients%2C%20feed%20phytoplankton%2C%20store%20carbon%2C%20and%20help%20us%20combat%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fjournal%2Fclimate-change-terms%5C%22%3Eclimate%20change%3C%2Fa%3E.%20Without%20whales%2C%20our%20oceans%20and%20planet%E2%80%94and%20countless%20animal%20species%E2%80%94would%20be%20in%20danger.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3EUnfortunately%2C%20deadly%20threats%20like%20ocean%20noise%20pollution%2C%20plastic%20pollution%2C%20collisions%20with%20vessels%2C%20whaling%2C%20and%20entanglement%20in%20fishing%20gear%20continue%20to%20push%20many%20whale%20species%20closer%20to%20extinction.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fjournal%2Fsustainable-whale-watching%5C%22%3EWhale%20watching%3C%2Fa%3E%20is%20a%20great%20economic%20alternative%20to%20whaling%2C%20and%20other%20initiatives%20to%20protect%20whales%20include%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fjournal%2Fsaving-right-whales-with-whale-safe-lobster%5C%22%3Ewhale-safe%20lobster%20fishing%20gear%3C%2Fa%3E%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fjournal%2Fslow-down-to-save-endangered-north-atlantic-right-whales%5C%22%3Evessel%20speed%20restrictions%3C%2Fa%3E.%26nbsp%3B%3C%2Fp%3E%3Cp%3E%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ifaw.org%2Fprograms%2Fmarine-conservation%5C%22%3ELearn%20more%3C%2Fa%3E%20about%20these%20threats%20and%20how%20IFAW%20is%20working%20to%20protect%20whales.%26nbsp%3B%3Cbr%3E%3C%2Fp%3E%22%7D%2C%7B%22id%22%3A407367%2C%22type%22%3A%22article_text_with_button%22%2C%22text%22%3Anull%2C%22button%22%3A%7B%22text%22%3A%22Donate%20to%20protect%20 <div><p class="_1NObY _2Nxbe">Types of whales: meet the largest animals in the ocean</p>
<h1 class="_39cEy _2Nxbe _1J8gu">Types of whales: meet the largest animals in the ocean</h1>
</div>
<div class="_2emWp _27AIz _32Qv3"><span>April 3, 2024</span></div>
<div class="QMpJu"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _3JsJ3 dwhqe" id="407352"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="_27NQg _3IRV-"><span class="jOf8B">Want to protect ocean life?</span><a href="https://secure.ifaw.org/united-states/join-ifaw" class="_1mtck" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><button class="_2sL5a _3yNq4 _1Idtl _33Rv-" tabindex="0"><span class="_30KW_"><span class="_1wgAr">Join IFAW</span></span></button></a></div>
<div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _28jJC _3-94C _37x9C"><p><a href="http://ifaw.org/animals/whales" target="_blank">Whales</a> are magnificent creatures. Not only are they highly intelligent, complex communicators, and the largest living animals on our planet, but they also <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/initiative/climate-change" target="_blank">protect us and the environment</a> by providing the nutrients that help phytoplankton (tiny marine organisms that use photosynthesis) <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/whale-poop-phytoplankton-climate-change" target="_blank">produce more than 50% of the world’s oxygen</a>. </p>
<p>Did you know that all species of whales are grouped into just <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/what-is-marine-mammal-complete-guide" target="_blank">two suborders</a>? There are 76 species of odontocetes (toothed whales), which use teeth to hunt for prey, and 14 species of mysticetes (baleen whales), which use baleen plates to filter food from the water. Baleen consists of bristle-like structures made from keratin—the same protein that makes human hair and fingernails.  </p>
<p>Baleen whales evolved from toothed whales, and they are some of the largest animal species on Earth. Toothed whales, on the other hand, are smaller on average, and this group also contains dolphins and porpoises. While baleen whales eat tiny organisms like krill and zooplankton, toothed whales feed on larger animals like fish and squid. </p>
<p>Here are some different types of whales within these two groups, how to identify them, and what makes them so unique. </p>
<h2><strong>Mysticetes (baleen whales) </strong></h2>
<h5>Humpback whale <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">Humpback Whale swimming off the coast of Tonga. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: © Vanessa Mignon</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407354"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>Acrobatic and charismatic, humpback whales (<em>Megaptera novaeangliae</em>) are one of the most well-known whale species and the stars of many whale watching tours. These baleen whales can grow to over 15 meters (50 feet) long and weigh over 36 metric tonnes (40 US tons). </p>
<p>Humpback whales are easily recognized by their long pectoral fins, which are the longest of any whale species—one-third of their body length. The humpback whale’s scientific name translates to ‘big-winged New Englander’. They also have an irregularly shaped dorsal fin and a hump that gives them their common name. </p>
<p>Knobby bumps on a humpback’s head are enlarged hair follicles called tubercles, which each contain at least one sensory hair. Their tails—called flukes—are unique to each individual, much like human fingerprints. Black and white patterns along with scarring on the underside of a humpback whale’s fluke help to identify it as an individual. </p>
<h5><br>
Blue whale <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">Blue whale swimming underwater. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: © Darin Sakdatorn - stock.adobe.com</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407356"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>The <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/blue-whales" target="_blank">blue whale</a> (<em>Balaenoptera musculus</em>) is the largest animal on Earth. This baleen whale can grow up to 30 meters (100 feet) long and weigh as much as 90 metric tonnes (100 US tons)—their tongues alone weigh as much as an elephant! Blue whales are sleek and slender, and their streamlined, blue-grey bodies appear bright blue underwater, which gave them their name. </p>
<p>In addition to being the largest, blue whales are also the loudest animals on Earth. They can emit low-frequency vocalizations as loud as a jet plane, which are heard by other whales hundreds of miles away. </p>
<h5><br>
Right whale <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">Aerial view of North Atlantic right whales (Eubalaena glacialis) at the surface of the water. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: © Nick Hawkins</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407358"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>The right whale gets its name from the fact that whalers called it the ‘right’ whale to hunt due to its slow swimming speed and large amount of blubber, which was used for its oil. As a result, right whales have been hunted to near extinction. Commercial whaling has been banned since 1986 around the world, but the practice continues in a few countries using loopholes in regulations. Today, all populations of right whales are protected by law. </p>
<p>There are four species of right whale: the North Atlantic right whale (<em>Eubalaena glacialis</em>), North Pacific right whale (<em>Eubalaena japonica</em>), Southern right whale (<em>Eubalaena australis</em>), and <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/bowhead-whales" target="_blank">bowhead whale</a> (<em>Balaena mysticetus</em>). The <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/north-atlantic-right-whale" target="_blank">North Atlantic right whale</a> is one of the most endangered species of whales in the world—there are only about 350 remaining. <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/campaigns/saving-the-north-atlantic-right-whale" target="_blank">IFAW is leading efforts</a> to protect this critically endangered species from the dangers of <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/north-atlantic-right-whales-terms-and-definitions" target="_blank">entanglement in fishing gear</a>, <a href="https://bluespeeds.org/" target="_blank">underwater noise pollution</a>, and <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/resources/ship-strikes-whales-prevention-factsheet" target="_blank">vessel strikes</a>. </p>
<p>Right whales can grow up to 15 meters (50 feet) long and weigh up to 63 metric tonnes (70 US tons). They have stocky, black bodies with white patches on their undersides. They lack a dorsal fin and have paddle-like pectoral flippers along with broad, smooth-edged flukes that help propel their massive bodies. </p>
<p>One of the most distinct features of right whales are their huge heads, which have roughened white patches called callosities. These are covered in whale lice, called cyamids. Each individual right whale has its own unique pattern of callosities, making them a perfect way for researchers to identify individuals. </p>
<p>Another distinctive characteristic of a right whale is the V-shaped blow or spout produced when it takes a breath. </p>
<h5><br>
Fin whale <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">Fin whale surfacing. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: © IFAW</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407360"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>The second largest animal on Earth next to the blue whale is the <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/fin-whales" target="_blank">fin whale</a> (<em>Balaenoptera physalus</em>), also known as the finback whale. Named for its prominent dorsal fin, which is two thirds of the way back on its body, the fin whale can grow up to 24 meters (80 feet) long and weigh up to 63 metric tonnes (70 US tons). </p>
<p>One of the fastest swimming whales, fin whales are nicknamed the ‘greyhounds of the sea’. Fin whales belong to the rorqual family—a group of whales that also includes blue whales and humpbacks—which means they have pleats or grooves around their throat that expand to take in massive amounts of water and prey. This is the perfect adaptation to grow to massive sizes! </p>
<p>Fin whales have streamlined grey bodies with irregular white patches called chevrons that begin behind their blowholes and continue down onto their sides. They also have asymmetrical coloration—the lower right of their jaw is white, while the rest of their jaw is grey. It’s thought that this asymmetry helps them corral prey while they are hunting. </p>
<p>In Iceland, fin whales sadly continue to be hunted. Partnered with IceWhale, IFAW created the <a href="http://www.ifaw.is/" target="_blank">Meet Us, Don’t Eat Us</a> campaign in Iceland to gain support for sustainable whale watching instead of commercial whaling and consumption. </p>
<p>Other baleen whales include minke whales, grey whales, sei whales, Bryde’s whales, Rice’s whales, Omura’s whales, and pygmy right whales. </p>
<h2><strong>Odontocetes (toothed whales) </strong></h2>
<h5>Sperm whale <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">Sperm whale swimming in the ocean. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: © Vanessa Mignon</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407362"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>Sperm whales (<em>Physeter macrocephalus</em>) are the largest toothed whales—as such, they are the world’s largest toothed predators. Growing up to 18 meters (60 feet) long and weighing 40 metric tonnes (45 US tons), the sperm whale has a dark grey body with a wrinkled appearance. It has a small jaw and a large, blunt head with one blowhole off centre on the left side. </p>
<p>Sperm whales are some of the deepest diving whales, spending more than an hour on dives at depths up to 600 meters to hunt for giant squid. While diving, they use echolocation clicks and pulses. </p>
<p>A primary target in commercial whaling, sperm whales are named for the waxy oil in the organ called their melon, a mass of tissue at the front of a whale’s head. This oil, called spermaceti, was used in products like candles and oil lamps. Nearly decimated by hunting in the 1800s, sperm whales are now endangered and protected throughout their range. </p>
<h5><br>
Orca <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">A killer whale at the surface in Iceland. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: Richard McLanaghan / © IFAW</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407364"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>Also known as the killer whale, the orca (<em>Orcinus orca</em>) is one of the most well recognized whales in the ocean, thanks to their distinct black and white color patterns. Technically considered the largest dolphin, the orca can grow up to 9 meters (32 feet) long and weigh up to 8 tonnes (9 metric tonnes). A male orca has a tall, triangular dorsal fin that can reach up to 2 meters (6 feet) high, while females have smaller, curved dorsal fins. </p>
<p>One of the most well-studied species in the world, orcas are highly intelligent and have complex social structures. They are known to be fierce hunters and have earned the nickname ‘wolves of the sea’. </p>
<h5><br>
Beluga whale <br>
</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="nlqHB" id=""><div class="xzXRG _11kC4 _2hAU1 _33sVo dwhqe"><div class="_2cRea"><figure><div class="_14xkW QushW"><div class="_47y7k CGH-Z"><div class="lazyload-placeholder"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="_2TL9k"><div class="_1Z5uT _1A2Yh"><span class="_2-_Xf">A group of beluga whales. </span><span class="_2Ca0I">Photo: Alexander Lyskin / © IFAW</span></div>
</div>
</figure></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="xzXRG B-dJ4 _28jJC _3-94C dwhqe" id="407366"><div class="-gEAI"><div class="uXf5I _3c5E- _37x9C"><p>The <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/belugas" target="_blank">beluga whale</a> (<em>Delphinapterus leucas</em>) is a species of toothed whale that lives in the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions of the Northern Hemisphere. Belugas grow up to 4.5 meters (15 feet) long and weigh up to 1.3 metric tonnes (1.5 US tons). </p>
<p>Belugas can be recognized by their uniform white color, which is how they received their name—beluga translates to ‘white’ in Russian. They have a round head with a bulbous forehead, where their melon organ is located. </p>
<p>As one of the most vocal whale species, belugas received the nickname ‘sea canaries’ by early mariners, who could hear their vocalizations through the hulls of their boats. </p>
<p>Other types of toothed whales include beaked whales, dwarf and pygmy sperm whales, <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/narwhals" target="_blank">narwhals</a>, and all <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/animals/dolphins" target="_blank">dolphins</a> and porpoises. </p>
<h2><strong>How can you help? </strong></h2>
<p>All whale species are incredibly important for the health of their ecosystems and the ocean as a whole. They circulate nutrients, feed phytoplankton, store carbon, and help us combat <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/climate-change-terms" target="_blank">climate change</a>. Without whales, our oceans and planet—and countless animal species—would be in danger. </p>
<p>Unfortunately, deadly threats like ocean noise pollution, plastic pollution, collisions with vessels, whaling, and entanglement in fishing gear continue to push many whale species closer to extinction. <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/sustainable-whale-watching" target="_blank">Whale watching</a> is a great economic alternative to whaling, and other initiatives to protect whales include <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/saving-right-whales-with-whale-safe-lobster" target="_blank">whale-safe lobster fishing gear</a> and <a href="https://www.ifaw.org/journal/slow-down-to-save-endangered-north-atlantic-right-whales" target="_blank">vessel speed restrictions</a>. </p>
<p><a href="https://www.ifaw.org/programs/marine-conservation" target="_blank">Learn more</a> about these threats and how IFAW is working to protect whales. <br>
</p>
</div>
